poem:
Bridging the Divide  

Brushstrokes spanning seas—   
a canvas binds us,   
whispering Vermeer's light,   
Rembrandt's shadows—the   
ghostly touch of old masters,   
rekindling whispers framed   
in restoration's glow.  
Atlantic murmurs stir   
in gilded halls anew,  
where old world meets the new,  
a silent dialogue,   
repainted with hope.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Art can help remind US and Europe of special relationship, says director of reopening Frick Collection Can masterpieces of European art help smooth over the fissures between the old world and the new? It’s a hope, say officials at the Frick Collection in New York, which reopens next month after a five-year, $220m (£170m) renovation. Axel Rüger, the director of the museum, which began with a trove of European masterpieces including Rembrandt and Vermeer, hopes". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
